document.docTitle: Cephennium (Geodytes) gladiator Jaloszynski & Struyve, sp. n.
document.masterDocTitle: A new subterranean Iberian Cephennium with unusually modified metatrochanters (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Scydmaeninae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new subterranean Iberian Cephennium with unusually modified metatrochanters (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Scydmaeninae)

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–2.
Cephennium gladiator
sp. n.
Dorsal (1) and ventral (2) habitus of male.

FIGURES 3–7.
Cephennium gladiator
sp. n.
, male. Humeral region of right elytron in dorsal view (3); head in ventral view (4); prothorax in ventral view (5); pterothorax in ventral view (6); intermetacoxal region and basal portion of left hind leg in ventral view (7). Abbreviations: bef, basal elytral fovea; bst, basisternal part of prosternum; cx, coxa; fe, femur; gp, gular plate; hd, humeral denticle; hyr, hypomeral ridge; mn, mentum; mscc, mesocoxal cavity; msvp, mesoventral intercoxal process; mtvp, metaventral intercoxal process; mxp, maxillary palp; nss, notosternal suture; om, ommatidium; pcr, procoxal rest; pm, prementum; ptp, posterior tentorial pit; smn, submentum; tr, trochanter; v3, metaventrite.

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. Metatrochanters in males strongly modified, each with blade-like projection reaching 3/4 length of metafemur; metaventrite in males barely discernibly impressed posteriorly; both sexes with eyes composed of single ommatidium; endophallus slightly elongate, bell-shaped, distinctly divided into lateral halves, in erected state with a pair of subtriangular, pointed distal projections.
Description. BL 0.88–0.90 mm ; body of male ( Figs 1, 2 ) strongly elongate and weakly convex, light brown, setae yellowish.

Head broadest at eyes, HL 0.11 mm , HW 0.15–0.16 mm ; vertex and frons confluent, covered with fine and inconspicuous punctures and short, sparse and suberect setae; antennal tubercles weakly raised but distinct; eyes composed of single ommatidium ( Fig. 4 ; om ), pigmented as lightly as surrounding cuticle, strongly projecting laterally. Antennae ( Figs 1–2 ) long and slender, with indistinctly delimited club composed of antennomeres IX–XI, AnL 0.34–0.35 mm , antennomeres I–II strongly elongate, III–IV about as long as broad, V indistinctly longer than broad, VI–X transverse, XI about as long as IX–X combined, about 1.8 × as long as broad.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 8–15.
Cephennium gladiator
sp. n.
, non-erected aedeagus of holotype (8−11) and paratype from Covelo (12−15) in ventral (8, 10, 12, 14) and lateral (9, 11, 13, 15) views.

FIGURES 16–21.
Cephennium gladiator
sp. n.
, erect aedeagus (16−19) in ventral (16, 18) and lateral (17, 19) views; left hind coxa, trochanter and femur in ventral view, extreme examples of variability (20, 21).

subSubSection.paragraph: Legs ( Figs 2 , 5–7 , 20–21 ) moderately long and slender, protibiae ( Fig. 2 ) lacking subapical notches; metatrochanters ( Figs 2 , 7 ) strongly modified, each with long blade-like projection on posteroventral margin, projection reaches 3/4 of metafemur.

Aedeagus ( Figs 8–19 ) elongate, AeL 0.28 mm in repose and 0.30 mm in erected state; median lobe in ventral view oval with truncated apex, endophallus located in subapical region, bell-shaped, elongate and with paired lateral components; parameres slender, each bearing single apical seta. In erected state ( Figs 16–19 ) endophallus completely extruded, subtrapezoidal, with a pair of apical subtriangular projections, each projection with serrate external margin ( Fig. 18 ).
Female. Differs from male in unmodified metatrochanters; BL 0.88 mm ; HL 0.10 mm , HW 0.16 mm , AnL 0.34 mm ; PL 0.28 mm , PW 0.30 mm , EL 0.50 mm , EW 0.33 mm , EI 1.54.

Etymology.
Gladiator
, Latin 'swordsman', derived from gladius , a sword; used here in its original meaning of a sword-bearer; refers to the sword-like projections of metatrochanters.

Additional collecting data . All specimens were collected from the soil under leaf litter (up to 40 cm deep) in natural acidophilous oak-dominated forests or remains of those within eucalypt plantations.
